subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
From {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*m-lawŋ||boat}}. Compare {{cog|my|လောင်း||long and narrow boat}}.

Sagart (1999) interprets Old Chinese {{och-l|船}} as a nominal derivate of the verb {{och-l|沿|to go downstream a river}}. The ''{{w|Fangyan}}'' states the this word was commonly used in western China, but, by Han times, it had completely desplaced the earlier {{och-l|舟||ship}}, used in central and eastern China.

Alternatively, the Proto-Sino-Tibetan root could be a loan from {{cog|mkh-pro|*d₂luuŋ|*d₂lu(u)ŋ ~ *d₂l(u)əŋ|boat}}, whence {{cog|mnw|ဂၠုၚ်|tr=klɜ̀ŋ|t=canoe, small boat}}, perhaps a derivate of {{cog|mkh-pro|*luuŋ(h)|*luŋh ~ *luuŋh ~ *ləŋh|to hollow, excavate, bore}}, see {{cog|km|លុង||to dig a hole}} and {{cog|vi|trũng||concave}} (Sidwell, 2006; Schuessler, 2007).
